subject: Re: [junit] Digest Number 1847
msgSnippet: ... If you add a couple of strategically placed interface keywords and delete the protected, you get this : public interface Node { void process(T
messageBody:
On 6/2/06, Robert Martin <UncleBob@...> wrote:
>
>
>
> I've pasted this into IntelliJ, with 1.5, but it doesn't compile.
> Moreover I can't parse it myself with what I know about generics.
> Does this look syntactically legal to you?
>
>
>
If you add a couple of strategically placed 'interface' keywords and delete
the 'protected, you get this :

public interface Node<T> {
void process(T value);

public static interface In<T> extends Node<T>
{
public void connectFrom(Node.Out < ? super T > node);
}

public static interface Out<T> extends Node<T>
{
public void connectTo(Node.In < ? extends T > node);
}
}

which IntelliJ likes much better.

Kevin


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
